column4: i would like to use ubuntu as my host os.. for work reasons, i must have an environment which will run vmware workstation reliably.. anyone here been running vmware workstation on ubuntu for a long time?
(i tried fedora once, but fell back to centos because of updates occasionally breaking vmware beyond what vmware-conf.pl would fix)
long time:no, reliably: yes
have you *ever* had an update break it (as in vmware-config.pl not able to reconfigure for a new kernel)?
it's not broke .. i'm currently running centos which has been rock solid for it... but i want to move to ubuntu for my host...
it tried fedora once but an update (even withthe proper header (suposedly) for the runnign kernel broke it
and i just don't want to get into a situation where i have to fall back to 'plan b' again
If it gets broken. just reinstall it, as long as your virtual machines are fine....
yeah.. i know.. but...
fedora had a miss-match of theheaders witht he running kernel at one point.. which meant that vmware-config.pl would nver work (even witht he support mod )
i ended up having to downgrade the kernel to get vmware back up...
but if you install the correct header on Ubuntu it will install fine
right..  i follow...
i just wanted to hear from someone using it that things work well
before i went through the bother of building another host environment
i've used vmware reliably since pre 1.0.. the fedora 5 hickup has been the only time i had a problem
sure. All I can say is that I have had VMWARE player (free) and Server (also free) and the work fine.
k.. i use player on most boxes.. but prefer workstation.. the extrea features are easily worth the cost :)
the whole snapshot thing is very sweet
yes, i have had workstation, and snapshoots sure are great...
not to mention the cloning, video, auto sizing of displays, etc
(creating video, not video cards)
yeah.. pretty much.. except you can clone a snapshot too
